awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Interpretable Deep Modeling of Discrete Time Event Sequences
awd_abstract_narration:
Discrete Time Event Sequences (DTES) are ordered event sequences with a concrete timestamp associated with each event. DTES are ubiquitous in our daily life. One representative example is patient electronic health records. Computational modeling of DTES can reveal the hidden event evolving mechanisms and improve the performance of endpoint analytical tasks such as sequence forecasting and grouping. Conventional approaches for analyzing DTES are typically based on strong statistical assumptions and may not work well in practice. Motivated by the recent empirical success of deep learning methods in various application domains, the objective of this project is to develop interpretable deep learning approaches for modeling DTES. This project validates the utility of the developed algorithms in various medical applications. It incorporates the resulting research outcomes into curriculum development and courses, to train a new generation of machine learning and data mining practitioners. In addition, special training opportunities are provided to high school students and community college students for a broader education of modern data analysis techniques.

This project consists of three synergistic research thrusts. First, it develops a series of approaches for integrating external domain knowledge into the modeling process. This guarantees the learned models align well with the domain knowledge and at the same time provides effective regularizations to avoid overfitting. Second, it devises approaches based on mimic learning and pattern dissection to interpret the knowledge hidden in the learned models. This makes the learned models much more practical and reusable. Third, effective model and data sharing mechanisms are developed to transfer the knowledge across similar learning tasks. This maximizes the utilizations of the available samples for each task by leveraging the task relationships. Two key problems in medical domain, hospital readmission and disease phenotyping, are used as the target applications for validating the proposed approaches based on several real-world large-scale patient electronic health record data sets.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A Discrete Time Event Sequence (DTES) is an ordered event sequence with a concrete timestamp associated with each event. DTES is ubiquitous in our daily life. One example, which is also the focus of this project, is patient Electronic Health Records (EHR) – by concatenating the medical events within each patient’s EHR according to their associated timestamps (from the earliest to the latest), we can obtain an EHR DTES. EHR contains tremendous practice-based evidence which could be invaluable to patient care; thus it is imperative to have appropriate computational tools that can dig these evidence out.

This project developed interpretable deep learning approaches for analyzing DTES and extracting insights therein. We have particularly investigated the following aspects: 1) Encoding existing biomedical knowledge into a knowledge graph, which can be easily incorporated by deep learning algorithms to make sure the mined data-driven insights align with known knowledge. We have built the integrative Biomedical Knowledge Hub (iBKH) for this purpose and made it publicly available to the research community; 2) Interpretation of complex models built for DTES analysis. We investigated the stability and robustness of popular post-hoc interpretation approaches including LIME and SHAP and developed methodologies to make them more stable. We have also leveraged them to explain the potential cause of algorithmic fairness; 3) Adaptation of algorithms in different scenarios, including different data sets with the same features as the source data set from which the model was developed, where the key is to quantify the feature distribution shifts, as well as different data sets with different features, where we have to handle the alignments of the distributions of both the shared features and across different features for the source and target data sets. We have developed a series of algorithms for the first scenario under personalized federated learning setting, and proposed a novel concept called patchwork learning for the second scenario.

With the support of this project, the PI was able to publish more than 60 papers on top conferences and journals, which include not only technical venues such as KDD and ICML, but also medicine and interdisciplinary journals such as Annals of Internal Medicine, Nature Communications and Science Translational Medicine. Many of these research works were widely reported in major media. The content of the research was incorporated into the tutorials the PI presented in various conferences, as well as the course the PI has been teaching. Moreover, the project has supported the research for multiple postdoctoral research associates and graduate research assistants.

 


Last Modified: 09/02/2024
Modified by: Fei Wang
